description:
Students and best friends Mizore Yoroizuka and Nozomi Kasaki prepare to play a complex musical duet, Liz and the Blue Bird, for oboe and flute. Though they play beautifully together and have been friends since childhood, Mizore and Nozomi find that with graduation looming and the duet proving difficult, their friendship begins to buckle under the pressure. Interspersed with their story is the fantasy tale of Liz, drawn like a storybook, contrasting with the crisp realism of the school.

(Source: Shout! Factory)

tags.name: Coming of Age
tags.description: Centers around a character's transition from childhood to adulthood.

tags.name: Band
tags.description: Main cast is a group of musicians.

tags.name: Primarily Female Cast
tags.description: Main cast is mostly composed of female characters.

tags.name: Fairy Tale
tags.description: This work tells a fairy tale, centers around fairy tales, or is based on a classic fairy tale.

tags.name: Unrequited Love
tags.description: One or more characters are experiencing an unrequited love that may or may not be reciprocated.

tags.name: Yuri
tags.description: Prominently features romance between two females, not inherently sexual. Also known as Girls' Love.

tags.name: School Club
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a school club scene.

tags.name: Primarily Teen Cast
tags.description: Main cast is mostly composed of teen characters.

tags.name: Classical Music
tags.description: Centers on the musical style of classical, not to be applied to anime that use classical in its soundtrack.

tags.name: School
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a primary or secondary educational institution.

tags.name: LGBTQ+ Themes
tags.description: Prominently features characters or themes associated with the LGBTQ+ community, such as sexuality or gender identity.

title.native: 劇場版 響け！ユーフォニアム～届けたいメロディ～
劇場版 響け！ユーフォニアム～誓いのフィナーレ～
特別編 響け！ユーフォニアム～アンサンブルコンテスト～

node.description:
[Twitter](https://twitter.com/ayanotakeda)

Ayano Takeda is a Japanese novelist. She aspired to become a novelist when she first read Risa Wataya's *I Want to Kick You in the Back* (蹴りたい背中, *Keritai senaka*). She made her debut while she was a student at Doshisha University with the short novel *Kyou, Kimi to Iki wo Suru* (今日、きみと息をする。). A story about a high school art club. She submitted the novel to the 8th Japan Love Story Award sponsored by Takarajimasha. Her novel was selected as a finalist. Although it did not win the prize, it was later published in May 2013 in the Takarajimasha Bunko collection.

In December 2013, she published her second debut novel *Sound! Euphonium: Welcome to the Kitauji High School Concert Band*. The novel was based on her days in the brass band club during elementary and junior high school. The novel was successful and spawned a manga and a popular anime series by [Kyoto Animation](https://anilist.co/studio/2/Kyoto-Animation). In 2021, she also won the 42nd Eiji Yoshikawa Literary Newcomer Award for her novel *Aisarenakute mo Betsuni* (愛されなくても別に).

In 2016, she was appointed as a tourism ambassador for her hometown in Uji City.

On September 25, 2022, she announced she got married to a man from outside the manga industry. On July 16, 2024, she announced the birth of her first son.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E5%B1%B1%E7%94%B0%E5%B0%9A%E5%AD%90) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Naoko_Yamada)

Naoko Yamada is a Japanese animator and director. She worked at [Kyoto Animation](https://anilist.co/studio/2/) from 2004 to 2020. 

Yamada enjoyed drawing as a child and would copy images from the [Patlabor](https://anilist.co/anime/324/) and [Dragon Ball](https://anilist.co/anime/223/) series. She joined the volleyball club in primary school and the tennis and photography clubs in high school. At the Kyoto University of Art and Design, she studied oil painting and was a member of the special effects club. She intended to work in film after university, but instead decided to join Kyoto Animation after seeing an advertisement. Her first assignment at the studio was drawing in between frames for [Inuyasha](https://anilist.co/anime/249/), which Kyoto Animation helped produce. She was eventually promoted to a key animator for [Air](https://anilist.co/anime/101/).

After working as an episode director of [Clannad](https://anilist.co/anime/2167/), she was asked to make her chief directorial debut with [K-ON!](https://anilist.co/anime/5680/), an adaptation of a slice-of-life manga. The series was very successful, spurring a second season and a film. In 2013, she directed [Tamako Market](https://anilist.co/anime/16417/), and followed it with the film [Tamako Love Story](https://anilist.co/anime/20519/) in 2014. For Tamako Love Story, she was awarded the New Face Award at the Japan Media Arts Festival. She storyboarded the entire film herself, and also wrote the lyrics for the opening theme song, “Everybody Loves Somebody.”

Yamada's next project was the feature film [A Silent Voice](https://anilist.co/anime/20954/), an adaptation of [Yoshitoki Ooima](https://anilist.co/staff/105951/)’s manga by the same name. The film reflected on elements of bullying and physical impairment in Japan. The film opened at #2 in the Japanese Box Office and grossed a total of ¥2.3 billion (~$21.7m USD), the 19th highest-grossing film in Japan in 2016. The film also received multiple award nominations, including Best Animation Film in the Mainichi Film Awards and the Excellent Animation of the Year in the Japan Academy Prize.

For Yamada, the most important part of being a director is to observe people. She describes herself as a "method" director, emphasizing the minds of the characters.

(Source: Wikipedia)

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/吉田玲子) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reiko_Yoshida)

Yoshida has written and supervised numerous scripts for anime series, live-action dramas and films. Her major works include [Kaleido Star](https://anilist.co/anime/427), [Aria](https://anilist.co/anime/477), [Maria-sama ga Miteru](https://anilist.co/anime/158), [D.Gray-man](https://anilist.co/anime/1482), [K-On!](https://anilist.co/anime/5680), [Bakuman](https://anilist.co/anime/7674) and [Girls und Panzer](https://anilist.co/anime/14131). In more recent works, she has supervised the screenplays for [Majestic Prince](https://anilist.co/anime/15863), [Non Non Biyori](https://anilist.co/anime/17549), [A Town Where You Live](https://anilist.co/anime/17741), [Tamako Market](https://anilist.co/anime/16417), [Yowamushi Pedal](https://anilist.co/anime/18179) and [Castle Town Dandelion](https://anilist.co/anime/20951). In films, she wrote the screenplay for Ghibli's [The Cat Returns](https://anilist.co/anime/597), the original films that would make up [Digimon: The Movie](https://anilist.co/anime/2961), Kyoto Animation’s hit anime film [A Silent Voice](https://anilist.co/anime/20954), and the film adaptations of Osamu Tezuka's [Buddha](https://anilist.co/anime/7014), the last one's [second film](https://anilist.co/anime/20500) was given a stamp of approval by the Dalai Lama.

Among her works, she was recognized for Best Screenplay/Original Work for [Girls und Panzer](https://anilist.co/anime/14131) at the Tokyo Anime Award Festival in 2014, and she won another Best Screenplay/Original Work award in 2017. In 2018, she wrote the screenplay for [Violet Evergarden](https://anilist.co/anime/21827) which aired on TV in Japan and is licensed by Netflix.

Yoshida also wrote the story for the manga series [Tokyo Mew Mew](https://anilist.co/manga/30554).

(Source: Wikipedia)

Futoshi Nishiya was a character designer and animator affiliated with Kyoto Animation.

He tragically lost his life alongside 34 colleagues in the Kyoto Animation arson attack on July 18, 2019.

__[Website](https://www.agraph.jp/)__ | __[Spotify](https://open.spotify.com/artist/4L0gz16xuM1as1OgYzh1SR)__ | __[Twitter](https://twitter.com/agraph)__

Kensuke Ushio, alternatively known by stage name agraph, is a Japanese musician, DJ, composer, arranger, programmer, remixer and member of rock band [Lama](http://www.sonymusic.co.jp/artist/lama/profile/).

When he was a child Kensuke learned to play the piano, while later at University he started studying arts and music, in addition to also learning how to use audio editing software like Pro Tools. At the age of 20, Kensuke first came in contact with the electronic music world known as techno. 

In 2007, he would start his solo career under the stage name agraph, this is when he started to create his own electronic music. His debut album titled A Day, Phases, produced by Takkyu Ishino, was released in December of 2008. Skipping to 2010, he would release his second album titled Equal which managed to rank in the Japanese Albums Charts.

In 2011, Kensuke and former musicians from the bands Supercar and Number Girl formed a rock band called Lama. The band has released two albums, which both managed to rank in the official Albums Charts of Japan.  It was later revealed that due to his involvement in the rock band Lama, he wouldn't be able to release a third album until 6 years after his second album. His third album titled The Shader was released in 2016.

(Source: Wikipedia)

__[Blog (JP)](http://forte-piano.net/)__ | __[Twitter](https://twitter.com/nijine)__

__Birthplace:__ Osaka Prefecture, Japan
__Residency:__ Tokyo, Japan
__Graduated:__ Nana Prefectural Sakurai Senior High School (2001), Osaka College of Music (2004)

__Introduction:__
Akito Matsuda, also known by his alias Nijine, is a Japanese composer and arranger. He worked freelance as a composer and arranger until his employment with Popholic found place in 2007.

__Biography:__
Akito is mainly known for working under the name Nijine, which he did between 2006 through 2012, where he wrote the soundtracks for a handful of anime while also composing and arranging various anime songs. In 2013, he decided to start using his real name for his work instead. He is also known for working on several eroge soundtracks and vocal songs under the name Tokia (stylized as TOKIA) early on in his career.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/鶴岡陽太)

Founder and representative director of [Rakuonsha](https://anilist.co/studio/211/).

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E5%B1%B1%E7%94%B0%E5%B0%9A%E5%AD%90) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Naoko_Yamada)

Futoshi Nishiya was a character designer and animator affiliated with Kyoto Animation.

He tragically lost his life alongside 34 colleagues in the Kyoto Animation arson attack on July 18, 2019.
Tragically lost her life alongside 34 colleagues in the Kyoto Animation arson attack on July 18, 2019.

Affiliated with [Kyoto Animation](https://anilist.co/studio/2/) since 1989.

Worked as an animator in the beginning of his career.

A prominent director and a key member of [Kyoto Animation](https://anilist.co/studio/2/).

After graduating from Osaka Designers' College in the late '80s, Ishihara joined Kyoto Animation and began his career as an animator. In 1991, he made his debut as a director with [Shiawasette Naani](https://anilist.co/anime/13441/). After that, he switched his focus to directing. Back then Kyoto Animation was still a sub-contracting studio, so therefore Ishihara could only get a handful of opportunities directing. Some of the shows in which Ishihara got to direct multiple episodes were [Tenchi Muyou!](https://anilist.co/anime/696/), [Aka-chan to Boku](https://anilist.co/anime/1485/), [Hyper Police](https://anilist.co/anime/1180/), and [Inuyasha](https://anilist.co/anime/249/). He also storyboarded the majority of the episodes he directed.

In 2003, Kyoto Animation started their transformation into a full-fledged animation studio producing their first anime series, [Fullmetal Panic? Fumoffu](https://anilist.co/anime/72/). Ishihara directed and storyboarded the 7th episode of the show. Two years later in 2005, he made his proper directorial debut directing the studio's second TV show, [Air](https://anilist.co/anime/101/). The following year he directed the award winning anime series, [The Melancholy of Haruhi Suzumiya](https://anilist.co/anime/849/). From here Ishihara has gone on to direct multiple of Kyoto Animation's acclaimed works.
He tragically lost his life alongside 34 colleagues in the Kyoto Animation arson attack on July 18, 2019.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/池田晶子_(アニメーター%29)

Shouko Ikeda was one of [Kyoto Animation](https://anilist.co/studio/2/)'s leading animators.

She went through the Yoyogi animation school and upon graduating joined Kyoto Animation in 1996. The same year she made her debut as an in-betweener on [Doraemon](https://anilist.co/anime/2471/). She also notably served as an animation director on the [Inuyasha](https://anilist.co/anime/249/) episodes that were outsourced to Kyoto Animation. In 2006, she was brought to the spotlight with [The Melancholy of Haruhi Suzumiya](https://anilist.co/anime/849/), a show in which she was the character designer and sole chief animation director. The designs of the series, as well as the general presentation was very well received amongst animation fans.

She has no blood relationship with [Kazumi Ikeda](https://anilist.co/staff/102724/).

On July 18, 2019, Ikeda was tragically killed alongside 34 of her colleagues in the Kyoto Animation arson attack.
Masahiro Oowada is a music director and conductor born in Miyagi Prefecture, Japan
Founder and representative director of Otonarium.
Shinichi Nakamura is a producer working for Pony Canyon.

Yasuhiro Takemoto studied animation at the Yoyogi Animation Academy. After graduating, he started working at [Kyoto Animation](https://anilist.co/studio/2/Kyoto-Animation) for almost his entire animation career, joining the company in 1996. At the company, Yasuhiro was considered one of the most reliable and trustworthy members of the staff. [Nurse Witch Komugi](https://anilist.co/anime/615/Nurse-Witch-Komugichan/) was his directorial debut​ and [Full Metal Panic? Fumoffu](https://anilist.co/anime/72/Full-Metal-Panic-Fumoffu/) his first solo directorial debut.

He died in the arson attack at Kyoto Animation's Studio 1 on July 18, 2019.

[Website](https://www.heart-company.co.jp/) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/Saito_S_HC)

Produces and directs music. Founder of Heart Company.
Affiliated with [Kyoto Animation](https://anilist.co/studio/2/).

A prominent director and a key member of [Kyoto Animation](https://anilist.co/studio/2/).

After graduating from Osaka Designers' College in the late '80s, Ishihara joined Kyoto Animation and began his career as an animator. He also storyboarded the majority of the episodes he directed.

In 2003, Kyoto Animation started their transformation into a full-fledged animation studio producing their first anime series, [Fullmetal Panic? Fumoffu](https://anilist.co/anime/72/). From here Ishihara has gone on to direct multiple of Kyoto Animation's acclaimed works.
